notesStmt.note: Edward Grier dates the handwriting of this manuscript to the 1850s in Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:203. The second paragraph of the manuscript contains phrases and ideas similar to lines from the poem "Miracles," in particular the phrase "Every hour of the day and night, and every acre of the earth and shore." "Miracles" was first published as "Poem of Perfect Miracles" in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass.

body.p: Such boundless and affluent souls. . . . . . . bend your head in reverence, my man! they are met through all the strata of life.—Their centrifugal power of love, I think, makes the awfullest forces of nature stand back.—Its perennial blow the frost shall never touch; and what we call death shall go round outside it forever and ever.—
